title: Meta’s Consumer AI App Struggles
description: The Meta AI app has persistent flaws, months after the company launched it. Bloomberg’s Natalie Lung discusses the issues and users’ reactions to the app with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)
content: This is the post-launch digest. Tell us what we need to know. Yeah, we have tested the app for a few weeks and asking it basic inquiries, asking if a personalized recommendations. And overall, we found the experience rather inconsistent and it felt a little bit half baked. For example, I asked it to give me recommendations on what to do over the weekend here in New York City, and for some reason it knew my zip code. I might have provided it to an advertiser one time, but I wasn't able to personalize it to that area. And the unique thing about it, apart from rivals, is that it has a Discover feed where you can see how others are prompting and interacting with the chat bot and they're like endless images. There you can see endless images that perhaps are not relevant to you. And sometimes the more edgy types of chat bots you might not want to interface with. Natalie What's so weird, as well as I interact with Metro, I actually more within the WhatsApp offering and maybe within the Instagram offering. Why is that? Not taking my data that I'm feeding it and bringing it over to Metro? I right now, all of those experiences are not connected, as you rightly pointed out. It is on WhatsApp, it is on Messenger, it is on Instagram, but they are not connected, which makes it a little bit far short of some of the, you know, personalisation ambitions that soccer world has.
summary: The post-launch of the controversial consumer AI app has been met with mixed reviews, with users finding the experience inconsistent and lacking in personalisation. The company's Discoverive feed also allows users to view other users' interactions with the bot. However, the company argues that these experiences are not connected, making it more difficult to personalise.
shortSummary: The post-launch review reveals mixed results for Metro, offering inconsistent recommendations and inconsistent experiences, with limited integration and connected experiences.
argos_summary: The post-launch review finds the app’s experience inconsistent and somewhat unfinished, with basic inquiries and personalized recommendations falling short. Users noted that the app could determine their zip code but failed to tailor suggestions to that area, and the Discover feed displayed irrelevant, often edgy images that may not suit all audiences. Additionally, the service’s presence on WhatsApp, Messenger, and Instagram remains disconnected, preventing seamless data sharing and undermining its personalization goals. Overall, the app shows promise but requires significant refinement to deliver a cohesive, user‑centric experience.
